publicationStmt.p: Distributed by Digital Scholarship Services at Lafayette College

lg.l: The humble petition of Frances Harris,
Who must starve, & die a maid if it miscarries,
Humbly sheweth,
That I went to warm myself in Lady Betty's chamber because I was a·cold,
And I had in a purse seven pounds four shillinlost in gutter & six pence, besides farthings, in money & golost in gutter
So because I had been buying things for my Lady last night,
I was resolv'd to tell my money, to see if it was right:
Now you must know, because my trunk has a very bad lock,
Therefore all ye money I have, wch, God knows, is a very small stock,
I keep in my pocket, ty'd about my middle, next my smock.
So when I went to put up my purse, as God would have it, my smock was unript,
And instead of putting it into my pocket down it slipt:
Then ye bell rung, & I went down to put my Lady to bed,
And, God knows, I thought my money was as safe as my maidenhead.
So when I came up again, I found my pocket feel very light,
But when I search'd, & miss'd my purse, Lord! I thought I shoud have sunk outright
Lord! Madam, says Mary, how d'ye do? indeed says I, never worse:
But pray, Mary, can you tell what I have donlost in gutter with my purse?
Lord help me, said Mary, I never stird out of this place:
Nay, said I, I had it in lady Betty's chamber, thats a plain case:
So Mary got me to bed, & cover'd me up warm,
However she stole away my garters, yt I might do myself no harm:
So I tumbled & tossd all night, as you may very well think,
But hardly ever sat my eyes together or slept a wink.
So I was a·dream'd, methought, that we went & search'd ye folks round
And in a corner of Mrs Dukes box, ty'd in a rag, ye money was found.
So next morning we told Whittle, & he fell a swearing;
Then my Dame Wadgar came, & she you know is thick of hearing;
Dame, said I, as loud as I could bawl, do you know what a Loss I have had?
Nay, said she, my Ld Galways folks are all very sad;
For my Ld Drogheda comes a tuesday without fail;
Pugh! said I but that's not ye business that I ail.
Says Cary, says he, I have been a servant this five & twenty years, come spring,
And in all ye places I liv'd, I never heard of such a thing.
Yes, says ye Steward, I remember when I was at my Lady Shrewsbury's,
Such a thing as this happend, just about ye time of Goosberries.
So I went to ye party suspected, & I found her full of grief;
(Now you must know, of all things in ye world, I hate a thief.)
However, I was resolved to bring ye discourse slily about;
Mrs Dukes, said I, here's an ugly accident has happend out:
'Tis not that I value ye money three skips of a louse;
But ye thing I stand upon is, ye credit of ye housecropped
'Tis true, seven pounds, four shillings, & six pence, makes a great hole in my wages;
Besides, as they say, service is no inheritance in these ages.
Now Mrs Dukes, you know, & every body understands,
That tho 'tis hard to judge, yet money can't go without hands.
The Devil take me said she (blessing herself) if ever I saw't!
So she roar'd like a bedlam, as tho I had calld her all to naught:
So you know, what cou'd I say to her any more;
I e'n left her, & came away as wise as I was before.
Well: but then they would have had me gone to ye Cunning man;
No, said I, 'tis ye same thing ye Chaplain will be here anon.
So ye Chaplain came in: now ye servants say he is my sweetheart,
Because he's always in my chamber, & I always take his part;
So, as ye Devil would have it, before I was aware, out I blunder'd,
Parson, said I, can you cast a Nativity, when a body's plunderd?
Now you must know he hates to be calld parson like ye Devil,
Truly says he Mrs. Nab it might become you to be more civil:
If your money be gone, as a learned Divine says, d'ye see,
You are no text for my handling, so take that from me:
I was never taken for a conjurer before, Id have you to know:
Lord, said I, don't be angry, I am sure I never thought you so:
You know, I honour ye cloth, I design to be a Parson's wife,
I never took one in your coat for a conjurer in all my life.
With that, he twisted his girdle at me like a rope, as who shou'd say,
Now you may go hang yourself for me, & so went away.
Well, I thought I shou'd have swoon'd; Lord, said I, what shall I do?
I have lost my money, & shall lose my truelove too.
Then my Lord calld me; Harry said my Lord, don't cry,
Ill give something towards thy loss, & says my Lady, so will I.
Oh! but said I, what if after all my Chaplain wont come to?
For that he said, (an't please your Excellencies,) I must petition you.
The Premises tenderly consider'd, I desire your Excellencies protection,
And that I may have a share in next sundays collection:
And over & above, that I may have your Excellencies letter,
With an order for ye Chaplain aforesaid; or instead of him a better:
And then your poor Petitioner, both night & day
Or ye Chaplain (for 'tis his trade) as in duty bound, shall ever pray.069-140B
